title: Supplemental Materials
text:
To extract the response patterns, we introduce the concept of conversation paths or conversation flows. These are chains of replies that start with a root post (the first post with the opening statement of a conversation) and end with a leaf (the last contribution to a conversation). Using these structures as the unit of analysis comes close to our understanding of a discussion and also facilitates the analysis process. It maps the complicated network structure to quasi-linear conversations that can be interpreted analogously to a real-life discussion.
Additionally, since social media sites delete tweets and posts that are against their policies and are also required to delete content due to legal requests, some of the trees contain missing references. For instance, if a tweet gets deleted, the corresponding reply tree is broken. Hence, each of the conversation trees was validated. In the common case of deletion, the orphaned branches were attached to the root post. As per definition, the root post does not include moderation. For this reason, this procedure does not lead to semantic errors.
Similar conversation modeling describes online conversations as polyadic conversations [@magnani2012conversation], reply-graphs [@cogan2012reconstruction; @joglekar2020analysing; @nishi2016reply], or implicit thread structures [@wang2021recovering]. This also allows the interpretation of a moderating post as an intervention: the result of the intervention can be computed as the sum of the effect on all conversation paths that include the moderating post. Moreover, most annotating tools are not equipped to deal with tree structures. However, if transformed into conversation flows, these can be analyzed qualitatively like any other transcribed group discussions.

title: POLISim Lab
text:
Practitioner Notes






Simulations and Role-Plays are common practice in Political Education
Educational (Computer) Games are well researched in terms of Learning Outcomes
Deliberation Analytics have profited from the rise of Artificial Intelligence





Political Education has overlooked Educational Technologies
Artificial Intelligence can be used to generate Role-Play Scenarios
Deliberation Analytics are missing in computer-enhanced Education





An Integration of Learning Technologies and Political Education
Cutting Edge Exploration of Artificial Intelligence for Learning Content Creation
A Method Toolkit to analyze Discussions in Learning Environments





Engineering with Profound Implications for both Society and Scientific Advancement
Rare Interdisciplinary Background in Computer Science and Political Education
An unusual and valuable Combination of Academic Skills and hands-on Software Engineering







The ability to talk to each other in a peaceful and productive manner is paramount for a society drifting apart. The proposed research group tries to contribute in a small way to solving these issues by facilitating teaching methods that address competencies needed for an open discussion culture. For this, modern technologies and computer-enhanced methods are used to foster a learning environment that promotes tolerant and open speech.
Computer technology has become an indispensable tool in educational research and practice. However, there is a gap in the case of computer-assisted political education, specifically the support of deliberation with role-plays. The aim of the proposed research group is to fill in the blanks by developing a software framework that addresses these challenges. This environment will seamlessly integrate simulations, deliberation, and learning analytics in the political education classroom.
Technology plays a crucial role in enhancing political science education by supporting both teachers and students in various ways. For teachers, it lowers the bar for using advanced methods by facilitating content creation, enabling the use of simulations to build intuition [@calderon_systematic_2015;@connolly_systematic_2012;@vlachopoulos_effect_2017], tracking learning outcomes [@Dehne2018_compbase_mobile;@Dehne2019_compbase_ple;@dehne2014], and overcoming barriers related to distance, language, and culture. For students, technology creates immersive learning experiences [@dishon_making_2020], offers flexible options for distance and personalized learning, and supports constructivist learning approaches [@bada2015constructivism] by providing a foundation for individual opinion formation [@chang_study_2011;@lo_adolescents_2017] and enabling self-regulated, creative learning environments [@Paa_en_2022].
Political Education in Germany tries to build deliberative competencies such as taking on perspectives, discussing using arguments and moderating uncivil statements. Role-plays, a well-established method in political science education [@petrik2017handbuch;@duchatelet_unravelling_2020;@duchatelet_looking_2019], are particularly effective in fostering the ability to take on different perspectives, understand institutions and procedures. It enables the training of essential discussion, rhetoric, moderation, and academic leadership skills. Their complexity can vary: the simplest form is a discussion between two students taking pro and con sides of a current issue like reenacting an American presidential debate. But it can also be a more complex procedure like the Model United Nations [@duchatelet_explaining_2021] where students are selected in a tournament mode from all over the world to sit in the real United Nations venue and discuss world politics. Sometimes this kind of role-plays is used as incubators for actual problems [@poole_becoming_2010]. Although simulations are not the only option to support political learning with technology, it is the most obvious choice. It is one of the strengths of computer technology to create a rich but unreal environment where social processes and political acts can be studied in a safe and ethical setting.
The proposed research group will be situated in the computer science faculty and focus on the construction and accompanying research of the learning environment. It is thus clearly located in the engineering field and will follow the customary methodology in that area [@peffers_design_2007;@vom_brocke_introduction_2020].


The planned simulation environment for political learning is composed of three primary components, each interconnected to create a cohesive system. The first component, the Scenario Creation (SC), supports generating [@davis_prompt_2024] and customizing the scenarios that drive the simulations. It leverages artificial intelligence to produce realistic scenarios [@vermeiren_assessing_2022], such as a European Parliament debate on a current issue, ensuring relevance and depth. Additionally, constraint programming [@gebser2011complex] is applied to tailor these scenarios according to specified parameters, including among others time limitations, learner group size, and the intended scope of knowledge.



The second component, the Role-Playing Game Environment (PPGE), provides the structural framework for the simulation. This modularized framework guides users through the simulation process, offering three distinct settings: institutionalized environments like Model United Nations [@duchatelet_explaining_2021], deliberation-focused discussions [@gold2017visual], and rational choice-oriented decision-making scenarios [@chen_otreeopen-source_2016]. This environment interfaces seamlessly with the Scenario Creation, allowing scenarios to be easily loaded into the system. To ensure flexibility and scalability, service-oriented principles [@Benatallah2008] are employed, enabling the decoupling of various elements. The environment is also going to support a range of hardware, from mobile devices to more complex setups like AR and VR [@Zender_Buchner_Schäfer_Wiesche_Kelly_Tüshaus_2022], creating a pervasive [@Zender2013] and immersive [@Mulders2023b] learning experience.



The final component, Deliberation Analytics (DA), offers an automated framework that provides valuable insights into the discussions taking place during the simulation. This framework is designed to be transferable to other use cases, such as the National Educational Platform [@gleiss2023governance], where it can enhance or moderate online forums. Speech-to-text technology is integrated, interfacing with mobile devices to access and display real-time analytics [@gold2017visual]. Using natural language processing (NLP) techniques, this component assesses the quality of discussions by analyzing interaction patterns [@dehne2023consistent], identifying key arguments through argument mining [@lawrence2017using], and measuring the fairness of exchanges, including time distribution and the presence of uncivil speech [@papacharissi2004democracy;@friess2021collective].
This design not only supports political education by making role-plays more accessible. It creates a laboratory for teaching and studying deliberation, too. This could then be used in various fields such as ethical AI, environmental studies and many other fields where a healthy discussion culture and student engagement is required. Moreover, it is situated at the intersection of the three fields of expertise of the applicant (computer science, education and political science) and thus would further qualify him for an academic career in computer-assisted (political) education and deliberation research.





Political education and similar pedagogies have been supported with various levels of computer technologies. These include websites [@asal_creating_2006;@chang_study_2011], emails [@handby_2021], PowerPoint [@meibauer_teaching_2018], mobile devices [@diacopoulos_systematic_2020], virtual games [@spangenberger_embodying_2024] and second life [@jamaludin_fostering_2009]. However, a targeted and comprehensive system such as the planned one is still missing.

In the literature, there are several calls to action aimed at increasing the use of the role-play method and promoting the integration of computer-enhanced learning: [@shellman_simulations_2006] argue that role-plays are an essential part of political science pedagogies and shift the focus from “saying” to “doing” which is important in developing skills alongside political knowledge. [@kammerer_2021] title their paper “Simulations Research in Political Science Pedagogy: Where is Everyone?”. They lament the heavy emphasis on publications and tenure, which leaves little room for exploring advanced pedagogical methods in political science. While role-playing techniques are commonplace in the field of international relations, they remain underutilized and insufficiently integrated into political science education in general. [@kaiser2017einfachdigital] argue that there is an initial hurdle because the technical construction of computer-supported role-plays would be complex, but if a system were in place, it could adapt well to changing asynchronous and distance-free scenarios. In summary, these calls to action highlight the method as highly relevant but hard to implement due to workload constraints. For this reason, computational methods are seen as an important enhancement, particularly in making the method more accessible and easier to integrate.

Simulations and role-plays are used in a number of application domains such as social work [@flaherty_teaching_2023], political theory [@handby_2021], climate change education [@fernandez_galeote_good_2022], business [@katzlinger_online_2008], in the medical field [@behler_eigentlich_2013] and many more. However, the method has the strongest match with the field of political education, as arguing, moderating, negotiating [@sun_assessing_2023] and taking on perspectives [@petrik2017alltagswelt] are prominent learning outcomes here.

In the field of political education the method is used mostly to teach about institutions and political systems [@cox_review_2014] that are complex and hard to connect to for the students such as the United Nations [@duchatelet_explaining_2021] or the European Union [@vermeiren_assessing_2022].

Although the preparation of the role-cards, scenario description, etc. are a lot of work, automated approaches have not reached the field of political education yet. Educators need to balance the overhead with the expected benefits when using the method. This effect is even stronger for serious games (educational computer games) [@malo_entwicklung_2008]. To address challenges in teachers’ workload, large language models such as ChatGPT have been used as a teacher assistant for lesson planning and personalization of learning material [@KASNECI2023102274], and generating personalized learning units [@kalota_primer_2024].

Serious games [@yi_designing_2011;@calderon_systematic_2015;@connolly_systematic_2012] have been a long time focus of the learning technologies community. However, there are few applications such as [@scheiner_2013] that try to integrate serious games and educational role-playing simulations. For one, the serious games movement came out of the rise of computer games, for another the role-playing is more related to a play (as in theater) than it is to gaming. However, many questions about software architectures, user experience [@moizer_approach_2019], learning analytics [@martinez_new_2022], and motivational arcs [@fernandez-sanchez_conceptual_2023] overlap between these modes. Therefore, it’s helpful to think of them as a continuum, depending on the extent to which characters are portrayed by humans or represented within a virtual environment.

In the extreme form the roles are reduced to a model of a human as a utility-maximizing rational actor [@avila-garzon_agent-based_2022;@andrade_sociological_2022]. This leads back to the political science research where rational choice experiments are used to model the effect of institutional changes or to understand the interplay of egoism and altruism in the human nature. As there already exists a software for the implementation of simulations [@chen_otreeopen-source_2016] the RPGE should integrate or extend the existing framework.


To evaluate the outcome of political role-playing a number of target learnings have been identified and studied. These include improved self-efficacy [@duchatelet_explaining_2021], negotiation skill [@sun_assessing_2023], structuring arguments [@sobernheim_structuring_2020] and the development of civic identities [@lo_adolescents_2017;@najjemba_engagement_2020]

All these learning outcomes combine to an improved deliberation level [@chambers_deliberative_2003]. These tools and insights can be transferred from the application field of analyzing deliberative quality in social media to the field of learning analytics. This is possible in the case of game-based learning as long as there is a live discussion as part of the game.



The research group will tackle the intersection of political education and learning technologies from the engineering perspective focussing on design principles, implementation and evaluation. To scientifically guide this process, it will try to answer the following research questions:

How can educational role-plays be designed to align with contemporary political issues?

What are optimal parameters, prompts or other settings that produce useful scenarios?
How can the generation be constrained to useful input for role-plays in an educational setting?

How can computers assist in improving situatedness and immersion in political learning role-plays?

What are the effects of game elements on the game-specific experience metrics?
What are the results in terms of technology acceptance and technical performance measurements?

What is the effect on learning outcomes given the complex interaction of method, situation, learning group and technology?

How can deliberation skills be measured?

To handle these multiple challenges, the group will consist of three PhD students in addition to the group leader who are going to focus on the three parts outlined earlier: the Scenario Creation (SC), the Role-Playing Game Environment (RPGE) and the Deliberation Analytics (DA).

In recent years, large language models like the Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT) have revolutionized natural language processing (NLP), particularly in their ability to generate coherent text, answer questions, and perform a wide array of language-related tasks with remarkable accuracy. These advancements stem largely from the adoption of transformer architectures [@devlin2018bert;@tay2022efficient], which have significantly enhanced the capability of models to manage long-range dependencies within a text. The transformer model, powered by the self-attention mechanism [@vaswani2017attention], excels at discerning the relevance of different text segments, regardless of their position within the input, allowing for a deeper understanding of word relationships and the generation of complex word sequences such as role-playing scenarios.
The SC is going to be based on the transformer architecture but will need modification to include the game aspects in the output. As a training input the German database of educational political simulations and similar resources can be used [@dechant2017planspieldatenbank; @rappenglueck2017praxis]. This part of the group will focus on finding optimal parameters, prompts or other settings that produce useful scenarios for role plays. Another challenge is going to be constraining the output to be useful and to cause little to no work for the teachers. Although this seems difficult, there are certain properties of the use case that make it likely that this can be achieved given the current state of artificial intelligence [@SALEHIN202452].
Transformer based text generation has been reported to produce hallucinations that don’t have any grounding in facts [@hallucination_2023]. But “Simulations do not necessarily require a high degree of realism, which is why web interfaces, desktop applications, augmented environments, or fully immersive virtual realities can be chosen depending on the use case. Combinations of these scenarios can also reflect different power dynamics in asynchronous applications, such as those of a coach (bird’s-eye view through a web application) and a learner (isolated through full immersion)” [@axel_2021] (translated using AI). It can also help to leave strong beliefs behind and be more open for the discussion. It is the teacher’s task in any case to transfer the learnings from the fictional setting to the presence.
The validation of the results could be in terms of usefulness, but the main evaluation will focus on algorithmic performance. For this reason, methodology from the NLP community will be prioritized. The same holds true for the constraining algorithms. For the above-shown reasons, the PhD student is going to need a strong background in computer science, particularly in the fields of NLP, Machine Learning or Logic Programming.
To ensure the best possible results, the PhD student benefits from strong connections at the University of Potsdam, which specializes in the research and teaching of constraint programming. Additionally, the group leader has expertise in this area, having previously taught the subject, and can contribute valuable insights and guidance.



Role-plays are a standard method in education in areas where perspective-change is needed and rational judgment (ger. Urteilskraft) of social aspects is relevant. In the political education classroom it is a typical approach to let students reenact two sides of a conflict such as pro and cons of a war decision or a presidential debate. This can also be much more elaborate up to simulations that can take a week.
One of the challenges is to support different levels on the continuum of role-plays and simulations. [@petrik2017alltagswelt] argues that the German word “Planspiele” (translates to ‘planned games’, the author) focuses more on conflict than on recipient-orientation which means that the planned institutional games are much more abstract and professionalized than the emotionality of acting in a role-playing exercise. In this case, the main conceptual challenge is to model these kinds of role-play variants.
This component is going to use concepts from serious game engineering [@hou_systematic_2023;@carlier_software_2023] and existing simulation software [@chen_otreeopen-source_2016]. The resulting software framework should support the various inputs and configurations the scenario creation provides. It is also necessary to generalize the game aspects to allow for different human-computer interactions, because “the use of simulations through VR or AR technologies […] allows conflicts experienced by learners to be authentically represented. As a result, data collection can be conducted in a laboratory setting while maintaining high ecological validity” [@HUANG2021104100] (translated using AI). Instead of overloading the software with all kind of implementations, it only needs to provide an interface for different scenario adapters. In one case, this could be a simple web interface, in another, an augmented reality setting could be supported where students simulate something more interactive like a United Nations conference. This approach keeps the workload for the software implementation manageable.
The PhD student is going to implement only one or two game types as a proof of concept for the framework that showcases the modularity and extendability. For this, the student needs a background in computer science with a focus on software engineering. A strong interest in game development is recommended, too. In terms of input, one scenario from the role-play database should be implemented as a minimal working example of the software architecture to avoid blocking dependencies from the first component.



Deliberation means a sensible, rational discussion where all the stakeholders come to a consensus that can be generally supported. It is a normative concept in political theory and can be traced back to Habermas’ discourse ethics [@habermas2009diskursethik] and Rawls’ A Theory of Justice [@rawls1975theorie]. It is a way of looking at discussions and assessing their quality [@steenbergen2003measuring] in terms of openness, tolerance and inclusiveness. The ability to participate in a productive discussion, use arguments, take on perspectives and moderate uncivil participants are important cornerstones of political education and beyond. To assess the result of role-plays, one way is to use the deliberative quality of the group discussion during the simulation as a proxy.
This part of the research group tackles the question of how deliberation skills are measured and how this ties into the existing research in the area of learning analytics. This is an important addition to the research group for the following reasons: a healthy discussion is not only relevant for a political education classroom. It should be desirable in all kinds of learning environments where group collaboration leads to dissemination and deliberation. Most significantly, it connects the research group to the strong trend of social media analytics in computational social science.
One of the technical tasks of this part of the group is to integrate the collection of speech data into the RPGE. Having access to an audio lifestream, speech-to-text technology is going to be used to have the discussion data available in the same format as discussion transcripts from social media. This is useful to reuse existing research and tooling [@dehne_dtrees_23;@duthie_classifying_2018;@gold_visual_2017]. In fact, the audio stream could also be directly piped into multimodal transformer models [@xu2023multimodallearningtransformerssurvey] if a more machine learning oriented approach yielded better results. The outcome of the analytics can be forwarded to the teacher or strategically presented within the RPGE right away.
Text data collected in the National Educational Platform [@gleiss2023governance] can be used as a provisional input to avoid a blocking dependency to an up-and-running RPGE.
The PhD student working on the DA part of the group needs a background in NLP, learning analytics or pedagogical psychology. A candidate from the field of computational social science might fit if the candidate can demonstrate strong computational skills.



Evaluating the effect of complex pedagogical interventions is challenging. The fourth role in the group is going to focus on integrating different quality markers into one comprehensive framework. These include the technical performance markers included in the SC, the RPGE and the DA. But this also includes the effect on the teacher in terms of facilitation and the outcome for the learners in terms of personal development. [@DehneWL17] argue that the interaction of technology and education has been biased by the idea that the impact of technology always needs be evaluated in terms of learning outcomes. They argue that in some cases, the technology enhancement allows for types of learning experiences that could not be achieved otherwise. Moreover, in other cases, the main advantage of the technology is to facilitate teaching and reduce the workload in a compressed academic system.
The project aims at recruiting a panel of experienced teachers and students enrolled in teacher education programs. They will participate in the iterative evaluation of the technology prototype, following the principles of Design-Based Research (DBR) [@Reinmann.Januar2015]. This panel will not only assess the usability and effectiveness of the technology in each development cycle but will also serve as a benchmark to compare the difficulty of using the same methods without the aid of the technology. By establishing this gold standard, the project will provide a comprehensive basis for judging the extent to which the software facilitates the educational processes it is designed to support. If possible, a double-blind study will be conducted at the end of the four-year span. The group lead heads the experimental setup and prepares the surveys and accompanying tests. He supervises the software development, too.
The overarching goal for the group lead is to develop a methodology of supporting political education with computer-technology. This encompasses …

… the use of AI to generate learning content
… the use of simulations to create an immersive and situated learning situation
… the use of natural language processing to improve develop learning analytics for political learning

The developed prototype addresses the relevant forward-looking research areas, allowing the conceptual research to be empirically validated. This ensures that theoretical assumptions and hypotheses can be supported through practical application and empirical data.





The hosting chair Prof. Lucke provides a successful and fitting environment for the proposed research group as it has an impressive track record in the field of learning technologies. Further, Prof. Lucke has a lot of experience developing and hosting bigger infrastructures for learning such as the EliS project and the BIRD project. She has also published in the area of serious games and immersion. Specifically, Axel Wiebke from her group is successfully researching immersion and learning outcomes using a virtual classroom setting which fits with the RPGE engineering. Tobias Moebert, also from her group, has published in the area of mobile games and is focussing his PostDoc research on complexity and AI which fits with the SC questions.
In the social science faculty, the research group of Prof. Juchler works on learning places, political education and theater and situated learning. Moreover, Prof. Juchler already can connect teacher candidates with the project as both participants and researchers.

Given the applicant’s previous tutoring experience with the Logic Programming Chair, their integration into this collaborative environment is expected to be seamless.

title: POLISim Lab
text:
The ability to talk to each other in a peaceful and productive manner is paramount for a society drifting apart. The proposed research group tries to contribute in a small way to solving these issues by facilitating teaching methods that address competencies needed for an open discussion culture. For this, modern technologies and computer-enhanced methods are used to foster a learning environment that promotes tolerant and open speech.
Computer technology has become an indispensable tool in educational research and practice. However, there is a gap in the case of computer-assisted political education, specifically the support of deliberation with role-plays. The aim of the proposed research group is to fill in the blanks by developing a software framework that addresses these challenges. This environment will seamlessly integrate simulations, deliberation, and learning analytics in the political education classroom.
Technology plays a crucial role in enhancing political science education by supporting both teachers and students in various ways. For teachers, it lowers the bar for using advanced methods by facilitating content creation, enabling the use of simulations to build intuition [@calderon_systematic_2015;@connolly_systematic_2012;@vlachopoulos_effect_2017], tracking learning outcomes [@Dehne2018_compbase_mobile;@Dehne2019_compbase_ple;@dehne2014], and overcoming barriers related to distance, language, and culture. For students, technology creates immersive learning experiences [@dishon_making_2020], offers flexible options for distance and personalized learning, and supports constructivist learning approaches [@bada2015constructivism] by providing a foundation for individual opinion formation [@chang_study_2011;@lo_adolescents_2017] and enabling self-regulated, creative learning environments [@Paa_en_2022].
Political Education in Germany tries to build deliberative competencies such as taking on perspectives, discussing using arguments and moderating uncivil statements. Role-plays, a well-established method in political science education [@petrik2017handbuch;@duchatelet_unravelling_2020;@duchatelet_looking_2019], are particularly effective in fostering the ability to take on different perspectives, understand institutions and procedures. It enables the training of essential discussion, rhetoric, moderation, and academic leadership skills. Their complexity can vary: the simplest form is a discussion between two students taking pro and con sides of a current issue like reenacting an American presidential debate. But it can also be a more complex procedure like the Model United Nations [@duchatelet_explaining_2021] where students are selected in a tournament mode from all over the world to sit in the real United Nations venue and discuss world politics. Sometimes this kind of role-plays is used as incubators for actual problems [@poole_becoming_2010]. Although simulations are not the only option to support political learning with technology, it is the most obvious choice. It is one of the strengths of computer technology to create a rich but unreal environment where social processes and political acts can be studied in a safe and ethical setting.
The proposed research group will be situated in the computer science faculty and focus on the construction and accompanying research of the learning environment. It is thus clearly located in the engineering field and will follow the customary methodology in that area [@peffers_design_2007;@vom_brocke_introduction_2020].


The planned simulation environment for political learning is composed of three primary components, each interconnected to create a cohesive system. The first component, the Scenario Creation (SC), supports generating [@davis_prompt_2024] and customizing the scenarios that drive the simulations. It leverages artificial intelligence to produce realistic scenarios [@vermeiren_assessing_2022], such as a European Parliament debate on a current issue, ensuring relevance and depth. Additionally, constraint programming [@gebser2011complex] is applied to tailor these scenarios according to specified parameters, including among others time limitations, learner group size, and the intended scope of knowledge.



The second component, the Role-Playing Game Environment (PPGE), provides the structural framework for the simulation. This modularized framework guides users through the simulation process, offering three distinct settings: institutionalized environments like Model United Nations [@duchatelet_explaining_2021], deliberation-focused discussions [@gold2017visual], and rational choice-oriented decision-making scenarios [@chen_otreeopen-source_2016]. This environment interfaces seamlessly with the Scenario Creation, allowing scenarios to be easily loaded into the system. To ensure flexibility and scalability, service-oriented principles [@Benatallah2008] are employed, enabling the decoupling of various elements. The environment is also going to support a range of hardware, from mobile devices to more complex setups like AR and VR [@Zender_Buchner_Schäfer_Wiesche_Kelly_Tüshaus_2022], creating a pervasive [@Zender2013] and immersive [@Mulders2023b] learning experience.



The final component, Deliberation Analytics (DA), offers an automated framework that provides valuable insights into the discussions taking place during the simulation. This framework is designed to be transferable to other use cases, such as the National Educational Platform [@gleiss2023governance], where it can enhance or moderate online forums. Speech-to-text technology is integrated, interfacing with mobile devices to access and display real-time analytics [@gold2017visual]. Using natural language processing (NLP) techniques, this component assesses the quality of discussions by analyzing interaction patterns [@dehne2023consistent], identifying key arguments through argument mining [@lawrence2017using], and measuring the fairness of exchanges, including time distribution and the presence of uncivil speech [@papacharissi2004democracy;@friess2021collective].
This design not only supports political education by making role-plays more accessible. It creates a laboratory for teaching and studying deliberation, too. This could then be used in various fields such as ethical AI, environmental studies and many other fields where a healthy discussion culture and student engagement is required. Moreover, it is situated at the intersection of the three fields of expertise of the applicant (computer science, education and political science) and thus would further qualify him for an academic career in computer-assisted (political) education and deliberation research.

Political education and similar pedagogies have been supported with various levels of computer technologies. These include websites [@asal_creating_2006;@chang_study_2011], emails [@handby_2021], PowerPoint [@meibauer_teaching_2018], mobile devices [@diacopoulos_systematic_2020], virtual games [@spangenberger_embodying_2024] and second life [@jamaludin_fostering_2009]. However, a targeted and comprehensive system such as the planned one is still missing.

In the literature, there are several calls to action aimed at increasing the use of the role-play method and promoting the integration of computer-enhanced learning: [@shellman_simulations_2006] argue that role-plays are an essential part of political science pedagogies and shift the focus from “saying” to “doing” which is important in developing skills alongside political knowledge. [@kammerer_2021] title their paper “Simulations Research in Political Science Pedagogy: Where is Everyone?”. They lament the heavy emphasis on publications and tenure, which leaves little room for exploring advanced pedagogical methods in political science. While role-playing techniques are commonplace in the field of international relations, they remain underutilized and insufficiently integrated into political science education in general. [@kaiser2017einfachdigital] argue that there is an initial hurdle because the technical construction of computer-supported role-plays would be complex, but if a system were in place, it could adapt well to changing asynchronous and distance-free scenarios. In summary, these calls to action highlight the method as highly relevant but hard to implement due to workload constraints. For this reason, computational methods are seen as an important enhancement, particularly in making the method more accessible and easier to integrate.

Simulations and role-plays are used in a number of application domains such as social work [@flaherty_teaching_2023], political theory [@handby_2021], climate change education [@fernandez_galeote_good_2022], business [@katzlinger_online_2008], in the medical field [@behler_eigentlich_2013] and many more. However, the method has the strongest match with the field of political education, as arguing, moderating, negotiating [@sun_assessing_2023] and taking on perspectives [@petrik2017alltagswelt] are prominent learning outcomes here.

In the field of political education the method is used mostly to teach about institutions and political systems [@cox_review_2014] that are complex and hard to connect to for the students such as the United Nations [@duchatelet_explaining_2021] or the European Union [@vermeiren_assessing_2022].

Although the preparation of the role-cards, scenario description, etc. are a lot of work, automated approaches have not reached the field of political education yet. Educators need to balance the overhead with the expected benefits when using the method. This effect is even stronger for serious games (educational computer games) [@malo_entwicklung_2008]. To address challenges in teachers’ workload, large language models such as ChatGPT have been used as a teacher assistant for lesson planning and personalization of learning material [@KASNECI2023102274], and generating personalized learning units [@kalota_primer_2024].

Serious games [@yi_designing_2011;@calderon_systematic_2015;@connolly_systematic_2012] have been a long time focus of the learning technologies community. However, there are few applications such as [@scheiner_2013] that try to integrate serious games and educational role-playing simulations. For one, the serious games movement came out of the rise of computer games, for another the role-playing is more related to a play (as in theater) than it is to gaming. However, many questions about software architectures, user experience [@moizer_approach_2019], learning analytics [@martinez_new_2022], and motivational arcs [@fernandez-sanchez_conceptual_2023] overlap between these modes. Therefore, it’s helpful to think of them as a continuum, depending on the extent to which characters are portrayed by humans or represented within a virtual environment.

In the extreme form the roles are reduced to a model of a human as a utility-maximizing rational actor [@avila-garzon_agent-based_2022;@andrade_sociological_2022]. This leads back to the political science research where rational choice experiments are used to model the effect of institutional changes or to understand the interplay of egoism and altruism in the human nature. As there already exists a software for the implementation of simulations [@chen_otreeopen-source_2016] the RPGE should integrate or extend the existing framework.


To evaluate the outcome of political role-playing a number of target learnings have been identified and studied. These include improved self-efficacy [@duchatelet_explaining_2021], negotiation skill [@sun_assessing_2023], structuring arguments [@sobernheim_structuring_2020] and the development of civic identities [@lo_adolescents_2017;@najjemba_engagement_2020]

All these learning outcomes combine to an improved deliberation level [@chambers_deliberative_2003]. The applicant has worked on creating software-packages i.e. [@dehne_dtrees_23;@dehne_social_media_24] to automatically analyze the quality of deliberation in discussions. He is also in the process of publishing a paper on the effect of moderation on deliberative quality using these measurements. These tools and insights can be transferred from the application field of analyzing deliberative quality in social media to the field of learning analytics. This is possible in the case of game-based learning as long as there is a live discussion as part of the game.

It is a way of looking at discussions and assessing their quality [@steenbergen2003measuring] in terms of openness, tolerance and inclusiveness. The ability to participate in a productive discussion, use arguments, take on perspectives and moderate uncivil participants are important cornerstones of political education and beyond. To assess the result of role-plays, one way is to use the deliberative quality of the group discussion during the simulation as a proxy.
This part of the research group tackles the question of how deliberation skills are measured and how this ties into the existing research in the area of learning analytics. This is an important addition to the research group for the following reasons: a healthy discussion is not only relevant for a political education classroom. It should be desirable in all kinds of learning environments where group collaboration leads to dissemination and deliberation. Most significantly, it connects the research group to the strong trend of social media analytics in computational social science.
One of the technical tasks of this part of the group is to integrate the collection of speech data into the RPGE. Having access to an audio lifestream, speech-to-text technology is going to be used to have the discussion data available in the same format as discussion transcripts from social media. This is useful to reuse existing research and tooling [@dehne_dtrees_23;@duthie_classifying_2018;@gold_visual_2017]. In fact, the audio stream could also be directly piped into multimodal transformer models [@xu2023multimodallearningtransformerssurvey] if a more machine learning oriented approach yielded better results. The outcome of the analytics can be forwarded to the teacher or strategically presented within the RPGE right away.
Text data collected in the National Educational Platform [@gleiss2023governance] can be used as a provisional input to avoid a blocking dependency to an up-and-running RPGE.
The PhD student working on the DA part of the group needs a background in NLP, learning analytics or pedagogical psychology. A candidate from the field of computational social science might fit if the candidate can demonstrate strong computational skills.



Evaluating the effect of complex pedagogical interventions is challenging. The fourth role in the group is going to focus on integrating different quality markers into one comprehensive framework. These include the technical performance markers included in the SC, the RPGE and the DA. But this also includes the effect on the teacher in terms of facilitation and the outcome for the learners in terms of personal development. [@DehneWL17] argue that the interaction of technology and education has been biased by the idea that the impact of technology always needs be evaluated in terms of learning outcomes. They argue that in some cases, the technology enhancement allows for types of learning experiences that could not be achieved otherwise. Moreover, in other cases, the main advantage of the technology is to facilitate teaching and reduce the workload in a compressed academic system.
The project aims at recruiting a panel of experienced teachers and students enrolled in teacher education programs. They will participate in the iterative evaluation of the technology prototype, following the principles of Design-Based Research (DBR) [@Reinmann.Januar2015]. This panel will not only assess the usability and effectiveness of the technology in each development cycle but will also serve as a benchmark to compare the difficulty of using the same methods without the aid of the technology. By establishing this gold standard, the project will provide a comprehensive basis for judging the extent to which the software facilitates the educational processes it is designed to support. Given that teachers are typically a challenging group to recruit for research studies due to workload constraints, this process will be coordinated with Lernen:Digital and the Potsdamer Zentrum für Lehrerbildung und Bildungsforschung (ZeLB).
To address the impact on learners, existing research on learning analytics and learning outcomes from role-plays in political education is going to be combined into an analytical framework. If possible, a double-blind study will be conducted at the end of the four-year span. In this study, the control group is going to take part in a set of classical lessons, whereas the test group executes the role-play in the constructed environment. The group lead heads the experimental setup and prepares the surveys and accompanying tests. He supervises the software development, too.
The overarching goal for the group lead is to develop a methodology of supporting political education with computer-technology. This encompasses …

… the use of AI to generate learning content
… the use of simulations to create an immersive and situated learning situation
… the use of natural language processing to improve develop learning analytics for political learning

The developed prototype addresses the relevant forward-looking research areas, allowing the conceptual research to be empirically validated. This ensures that theoretical assumptions and hypotheses can be supported through practical application and empirical data.

title: Motivational Letter
text:
My main source of motivation is high intrinsic interest in academia and my strong affinity for teaching that lead me to train as a high-school teacher in the first place. My research interests reflect my diverse background in social sciences, education and computer science. But instead of seeing this as a disadvantage in a competitive environment where specialization matters most, I embrace it as my identity that as a scientist, naturally, I am a curious person that sees the world as interconnected and fascinating in its many interlacing fields of study.



Collaborative Self-Regulated Learning: During my PhD I developed a software that supported student centered collaborative learning. However, in the absence of the leadership of a teacher, the question of how student behavior can be regulated and objectively evaluated are hard to answer. Learning analytics may help the teaching staff to find and design the right point of intervention. Creating a technological environment that includes enough manifestations of the self- or group-centered learning processes in order to form a decent picture remains one of the major challenges in the field of learning technologies.
Creative Learning: During my time at Humboldt university I authored a paper on the operationalization of creativity for the field of learning technologies. Implementing these concepts in a learning environment would also make it more democratic in the sense that lateral thinking is given the credit it deserves alongside classical factors such as intelligence, logic and memory skills. Technology is uniquely suited to support more complex tasks that can analyze creative learning processes.
Learning Outcomes: For the area of learning outcomes the goal was to create a general purpose generic competence-database. The basic idea was that all kinds of learning technologies share internal persistence of learning outcomes and could be integrated within paradigm of service oriented architectures.
Peer Assessment: Also within my PhD I worked on new ways of peer assessment that included a combination of student and teacher influence. My stint at computational social sciences also gave me the idea to include rational choice experiments common in the political sciences in the area of learning technologies.

A common theme is that past and planned research take place in predominantly uncharted and less known methodological spaces where it is hard to produce large quantities of papers that detail different aspects while maintaining a core methodological access point. However, while this may be a disadvantage during the focused PhD stage or even overwhelming when being the core developer in a postdoc project, I strongly believe that given the chance I could promote these issues from the fringes to a more central position within the communities of learning technologies and higher education. It is also the case that some of these issues have become more prominent lately, so that it should be easy to find suitable partners for collaboration. Here I have good starting points with the members of the projects I have worked for but also beyond.



Over the past three years, I have dedicated myself to the field of computational social sciences. Although this was a detour from my primary focus on learning technologies, this experience allowed me to gain significant expertise in applied machine learning and natural language processing.
Now, I am eager to apply these skills back to the field of learning analytics, where numerous application areas await. For instance, during my PhD, I worked on the COMPBASE project for three years which deals with creating a persistence for learning outcomes across elearning projects. This project was significantly hindered by the challenge of matching similar learning outcomes—a task that large language models can now handle with ease.
There are many more potential applications for these advanced tools in learning analytics, and I would be thrilled to have the opportunity to return to my original field equipped with these new competencies.



I have been a researcher both in the field of educational technologies and in the field of higher education. For the stage in my career I feel well-connected to the respective communities through the GI and the DGHD. For instance, I have been part of the PC for the DELFI the last years, and I graduated from one of the most prominent learning technologies working group.
In terms of academic background and methodological skill I bring an especially broad set of perspectives. To paraphrase one of my mentors: yes, the academic world requires specialization and most permanent positions ask of you to be the best in the field, but it is also true that your academic identity is not the lowest common denominator but the union of the fields (education, computer science and political science) you have graduated and worked in.

Thank you for your consideration!

title: Paper 14
text:
The paper discusses means of automated classifications of Calls To Actions by political parties. Using LLM-generated synthetic data, a BERT-model is fine-tuned successfully, so that it can distinguish calls to actions from other posts and stories on Instagram. This is contrasted with zero-shot/few-shot prompts that directly classify Instagram content.



The research fills a methodical gap to automate the analysis of social media posts by different parties in regard to CTAs. It showcases the knowledge of current technologies and also provides educational material for political scientists less experienced in the CSS field. It is well written. The language is clear and to the point. In short: it all makes sense.



The authors use current technologies that are compared with each other. Using human annotation as external validation it remains unclear why two solutions to the same problem are presented. Neither of the solutions is innovative in the sense that it would need to be compared to the mainstream approach. In theory, other options like Naive Bayes, regular expressions or simple dictionary approaches could have been added to the mix. It is understandable why these trending technologies are used but it appears to follow more the current hype than an internal logic of selecting the best method for the job.



The main problem lies in the sampling process. The authors note themselves that the observation period is short, the N is low and the sampling strategy of using two prominent party accounts as entry points is problematic. The discussion of interpretation errors such as the question of whose job in the party it is to send out call for actions are missing.



On a technical and grammatical level the paper is very solid. Code availability and open science aspects should be discussed.

Using LLM-generated synthetic data, a BERT-model is fine-tuned successfully, so that it can distinguish calls to actions from other posts and stories on Instagram. This is contrasted with zero-shot/few-shot prompts that directly classify Instagram content.

title: Paper 14
text: The research fills a methodical gap to automate the analysis of social media posts by different parties in regard to CTAs. It showcases the knowledge of current technologies and also provides educational material for political scientists less experienced in the CSS field. It is well written. The language is clear and to the point. In short: it all makes sense.

title: Paper 14
text: The authors use current technologies that are compared with each other. Using human annotation as external validation it remains unclear why two solutions to the same problem are presented. Neither of the solutions is innovative in the sense that it would need to be compared to the mainstream approach. In theory, other options like Naive Bayes, regular expressions or simple dictionary approaches could have been added to the mix. It is understandable why these trending technologies are used but it appears to follow more the current hype than an internal logic of selecting the best method for the job.

title: Paper 14
text: The main problem lies in the sampling process. The authors note themselves that the observation period is short, the N is low and the sampling strategy of using two prominent party accounts as entry points is problematic. The discussion of interpretation errors such as the question of whose job in the party it is to send out call for actions are missing.

text: On a technical and grammatical level the paper is very solid. Code availability and open science aspects should be discussed.

title: Paper 14
text:
Summary
The paper presents a study on the complexity (and specific features) of populist speech. It argues that there are certain well-known rhetorical devices that distinguish populist and non-populist speeches.

title: Paper 14
text:
Contribution to Research
The main contribution is debunking the claim that simple measures of complexity capture populist language. It provides a well-rounded approach of comparing different measures while reusing an existing dataset.

title: Paper 14
text:
Methods
The methods employed are fairly straight-forward. Using an existing dataset skipped sampling or selection in the research process. Even though this is very efficient the results might not be easy to generalize. From there, the authors computed the measures they were interested in and ran LASSO regression for feature selection. Logistic regression was used to determine significant features.

title: Paper 14
text:
Main Limitations
For the reviewer the link between the theory (complexity language) and the selection process of features and statistical analysis could be clarified. Also, the political character of populism could be integrated. Demagogues exist outside the political arena and for a workshop specialized on political speech the non-linguistic literature of political rhetoric is missing. Since this is one of the most prominent topics in political theory since Cicero, it should be possible to leave the disciplinary bubble here. For example the rule of three is an ancient rhetorical device called tricolon.
Although it is refreshing to not see AI-based methods, complexity specifically might be better glimpsed at with large language models as they might be able to capture more semantics.

Dear Hiring Committee,
I am writing to express my strong interest in the position of Head of Digital Humanities at the Max Planck Institute for the History of Science. With a robust background in computational social science, digital humanities, and e-Learning, I am excited about the opportunity to lead your Digital Humanities team and contribute to the innovative research environment at MPIWG.
My career began in learning technologies, where I developed the ability to communicate effectively within large interdisciplinary teams and to build complex architectures that address social science research questions. My dual qualifications in computer science and political science have often placed me in the role of translator and moderator—skills that are crucial for fostering collaboration across diverse research groups and external partners in the digital humanities.
My fascination with computational social science began in 2008, during my studies in both computer science and political science. Although computational social science was not formally recognized as a field at the time, my interests naturally converged. I was particularly drawn to the potential of advanced language models for analyzing political culture, a vision that has since become a reality as these methods now dominate the field. My work, grounded in deliberation theory, has allowed me to develop a unique interdisciplinary approach that aligns closely with the digital humanities.
The challenges, skills and problems are very similar in the computational social science field, the learning technologies and the digital humanities even though humanities and social sciences as such are very different. This is a position I would be happy to defend in a personal interview.
The position at MPIWG demands a strong foundation in computational social science, natural language processing, machine learning, and database management—areas where I excel due to my formal training and experience in both computer science and social science research. My technical expertise, coupled with my ability to communicate complex mathematical concepts, has been honed through years of teaching computer science. Furthermore, my engineering experience is highly relevant as research systems in digital humanities continue to grow in complexity.
I attended a Gymnasium with a strong humanistic focus, where I studied Latin, Ancient Greek, and philosophy. Although my career has since taken a more technical direction, this academic foundation continues to shape my personality and interests. My research has consistently been driven by a deep engagement with methodology, epistemology, and transdisciplinary thinking, as reflected in many of my publications. This blend of humanistic and technical expertise makes the opportunity to work in the humanities while contributing through technical innovation an ideal fit for my character.
The intersection of digital humanities and computational social science mirrors the interdisciplinary skills and epistemic approaches that have shaped my career. My experience in e-Learning has also reinforced my belief in the power of digital tools to transform traditional humanities research. I am confident that my background, combined with a fresh perspective and a strong motivation to advance the field, makes me an ideal candidate for this position.
I look forward to the possibility of contributing to the Max Planck Institute’s ongoing success in integrating digital methods with research in humanities and to fostering innovative collaborations within and beyond the Institute.
Thank you for considering my application.
Sincerely,
Julian Dehne

title: Cover Letter
text:
Cover Letter
The Goethe-University Frankfurt was the first I studied at - for three weeks. For this reason it is usually not even mentioned on my CV. After spending a lot of my childhood in Africa, I wanted to study anthropology and ethnography. However, I quickly realized that my interest was more in the direction of political science. Having studied Latin and Ancient Greek at school, I was deeply interested in philosophy and especially political theory. For this reason I decided to study European Studies in Passau which was promised to combine cultural studies and political science. Here, I learned the meaning of critical theory and read Habermas for the first time.
Fast-forward 15 years: I have now established myself in the field of computer science. Algorithms and computer technology seem to dominate my world and I believe that if you want to critically analyse something you should understand the nuts and bolts of it. During my PostDoc years in Göttingen I was tasked to develop an algorithm that could detect moderation on social media that supports deliberation. Quickly, I understood that I had to go back to the roots. I read the Frankfurt School but was challenged from my colleagues that were American-educated and based their definitions on the Pragmatism. I spend a good part of 2022 and 2023 to reconcile what I had learned earlier about critical theory with the books of Hans Joas and other pragmatists. When I tried to bring in these thoughts, the quantitatively minded political science community rejected my papers.
The majority of my time in academia was spent in the field of learning technologies. However, I always felt that the field was biased towards a positive effect of technologies on the society and lacked critical thinking. I have not published a lot (in general) because my papers were usually seen as too critical towards the mainstream research. Ironically, when I followed the trend by supporting inquiry with technology during my PhD, I was awarded the best paper (GMW 2017).
Shortly after completing my PhD, I was diagnosed with heavy rheumatism. It took some time until a suitable medication was found that would not limit my concentration. By that time the chance to apply for junior professorships was over. As a consequence, I decided to switch fields to computational social science, because I had given up on an academic career and wanted to pursuit what was of interest to me.
In the new field, I found joy in the research but being new in the community made it hard to publish immediately. I think I have now fully arrived in the CSS community and can follow the current discussion on artificial intelligence both on the technical and on the level of its effects on learning. Still, I think that technology-enhanced learning is not viewed from a critical perspective and I would be happy to be a scholar in this particular field. I know that my publication record is far off the mark for a professorship. But my goal is an assistant professorship (Akademischer Rat) with focus on teaching as this is my profession (I am a trained high school teacher).

Thank you for considering my application!
Julian Dehne

title: Introduction
text:
Introduction
Technology based learning plays a central part in the modern educational system. I have been asked a lot of times what my work as a researcher in online-based learning systems looks like, why it is interesting, and what the applications might be. After the COVID pandemic these questions seized. The piano teacher in the family who had almost no digital competences suddenly had to teach piano online. But shifting the teachings to the online sphere, so called digitalization, was not very successful. The same methods were applied but some practical aspects like guiding the fingers could simply not be transferred. The problem was that selectively using the advantages of technologies for learning whilst being aware of the limitations requires an extraordinary amount of training. Moreover, most technologies are not available in a simplified, tailored version that someone who has played and taught piano all her life could use. The result was the same everywhere: frustration with the new substitute methods, seemingly worse results, and no lasting changes to the educational system. During the COVID pandemic I switched my field of research to computational social sciences because I was equally frustrated: 30 years of research into computer-based learning, 10 of which I participated in were soundly ignored despite an overwhelming sudden relevance of the field. After a certain period of calming down I realized that the fault was not only with the politicians who did not differentiate between creatively using technology for the betterment of learning outcomes and the digitalization of administrative processes which they were involved in themselves. Nor did the fault lie with the teachers who were not accustomed to computers, digital whiteboards, or mobiles. The problem was that even experts in the field could not say for sure which technologies could be trusted to have a positive effect on learning outcomes. Evaluating learning outcomes is an extremely complex task. So is assessing the impact of technology, or modelling the impact technology has on humans. These questions are so difficult that there have emerged scientific fields solely dedicated to these: pedagogical psychology, human computer interaction, learning technologies and many more. The goal of this book is to develop a methodology for developing sound and standardized studies of the interplay of technology and learning, so that when the need arises, our community has more substantial lessons, and more practical tools to offer. It also allows me to delve into the philosophy of education, the sociology of technology and the fascinating interdisciplinary lines that results in different concepts of science. It is targeted at the new generation of PHD students in the field of learning technologies that are flabbergasted by the chaos as well as more experienced researchers who are interested in the philosophical reasoning for making informed practical choices.

title: Short Explanation of Selection
text:
All three papers illustrate my will to challenge the assumption that technology supports better learning. Riding on the digitization wave, a lot of research has tried to justify spending on technology by pushing computer-assisted learning support. However, empirical evidence to the improvement of learning outcomes is missing. I have been on both sides of this question. Most of my research has been funded by the same trend. Still, I have felt that the direction was misguided which led to me writing some critical papers on the matter.


Here, I explore the option to use technology to enhance creative learning. This paper is important to me because it was the last I wrote in the field of learning technologies. After this, I switched fields because I could not stand the idea that we could someday teach our children by measuring their creative output. Nevertheless, I showcase my ability to link seemingly unconnected fields and think between disciplines.



In this paper I ask whether technology-based learning can be evaluated and propose some approaches. When I submitted this paper the reviewers were divided. Some wanted to give me the best paper award. Others wanted to reject it. I think with this paper I started a meaningful discussion in the community of how we evaluated the effect of technology on learning outcomes.



During my PhD, I was tasked to model the inquiry based learning process in order to support it with learning technologies. I build a software that did not target inquiry itself but tried to improve collaborative processes by making them more efficient and by constructing a blueprint for a learning process that is peer-regulated thus following the ideal of Humboldt that students and staff should intermingle and think together.

I am happy to apply for the PostDoc position in Computational Social Science due to my profound interest and the very close fit with my experience and technical skills.
Over the last three years I worked in Göttingen on a project called Deliberation Laboratory. The goal was to develop a chatbot that could interact with social media before discussions escalated and became hateful. Here, we have established a theoretical basis, developed a research design, and carried out a human-in-the-loop experiment. The main study almost culminated, and I would be thrilled to continue the work and bring in all the insights to Zurich. It feels like I have just fully arrived in the CSS community. Currently, I am collaborating with three PhD students on their projects and ideas for project proposals are abundant.
